Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 03:42PM - edited Jul 25, 2008 03:57PM by myheidiscrapbooking Hi Rsea22, and all others :)   Yes, you are right. My hospitals BOTH told me that "multi-focal" is "starndard mastectomy" across the board, but, they think they put that out there when they are dealing with "masses" and ofcourse that has the "safest" results.  However,both hospitals told ME that each "multi-focal" is different and it really does depend on the type of cancer, location ect. and is NOT across the board - but, instead told me that they believe in looking closer at each person's "multi-focal."  I got two separate opinions-and both told me that cancer can show up any where in your body, ofcourse -  I KNOW that can happen especially since its in my lympnodes (two to be exact) and multi-focal (3 tumors) (maybe 4?) however.. .and big however. ...I also know that both multi-conferences at two diff. hospitals in Mass. told me that IF it does "re-occur" in my breast, that I have to have a mastectomy after this most definately. I am totally choosing to take a chance on it NOT re-occurring and trying to keep my breasts. I know its more popular to just take them off and not worry., believe me.  I KNOW this is a very difficult decision and its really up to each person personally - we all know what we can handle!!!  I know that my percentages of keeping my  breast (having three tumors close together in same quadrant) and-I was told by both really good hospitals- (multi-focal and not multi-centric ofcourse) gives me a 8-10% of re-occurance in my same breast OR, if I have it the breast off (one breast w/cancer) 2-3% of re-occurannce in the future.  I know its not a decision for the light-hearted. Its very scary to me - believe me. However, after much agonizing, I'm going to take the chance and keep my breasts and pray it doesn't come back. If it does, I was told that I would have to have no chemo, would have to have radiation again and have my breast taken off. Again, both said it was rare to occur (IDC) in both breasts if was only in one. Lobular I was told was much more likely to occur in the other breast not IDC) . Again, for me, I am going to take the chance. I know most of you must think Im crazy. The reason I get thru this is because it won't "up" my chances of getting it in my other areas, or organs, AND  affect my overall survival rate. These percentages only refer to my breasts. Keeping my breasts won't make the cancer more likely to go to my organs I am told.  Again, I know this is not an easy decision. I aggonize, believe me!!!. I dont know if I'm making the right decison and will regret it eventually. Like everyone, Im taking a chance that I will be pissed off if it does in fact come back in a year and I have to get a mastectomy AND rad. again. I just finished chemo and that was a big question for me as well. THey told me most likely I would not repeat chemo if it re-occured. This is such a personal decision for everyone. I will say I have been married for 17 years however I do not have children. I think that would be a bigger decision - as well as your life circumstances with other family members, spouses, ect.  I just wanted to relay my experience and decision - I just really want to keep them and see what happens. I am obviously hoping for the best and my two opinons have been very upfront with me and agree. They can only give stats. I understand and this is what I chose. As for everyone else, it truly is what you can take, given your own situation.   I have a tendency to ramble and repeat. SORRY!!!! Heidi

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 11:46PM myheidiscrapbooking wrote: Jim, I read your first post. I did not read posts afterwards so I am responding fresh. I also had a 1.3cm tumor in right breast - and while they did the lumpectomy, found another small 3mm tumor in front. They then told me that because it was now called "multi-focal" I would have to do chemo. I also had two lympnodes found with cancer. However, if no lymphnodes were found and just those two lumps, I would still have chemo. I will tell you, it was a scary ride (where you are now) I am now on chemo (day 7) and honest to god, have not had one side-effect. Matter of fact, my oncology appt. was today and I asked if she thought it was actually working :) She said that chemo today is SO much different. I was literally in a state - of fear about chemo and really nothing else. My husband was too. However supportive, I knew that the chemo would scare both of us. We are dancing on clouds as we cannot believe how easy it has been. Your wife will have lots of drugs for side-effects.  I am actually off the drugs now (as of day 5) because of no side effects. Things are a lot better today than prior. I had to write because your situation seemed similar to mine. Im 47 and I also was just told that even though it is "multi-focal" - (same cancer but in more than one place) that I didnt even have to remove my breast - I thought for sure, when they found more after the fact, that was it for my breast. It wasn't. I had two opinions - Beverly Hospital in Mass. and also famous Beth Isreal in Boston whom was the one that really thought I could save it. It would not lower my overall survival rate. If it isn't in her lympnodes, she could be 100% curable. If it is, my rate was 80% in remission. I've talked to many women now and all had no reoccurance. Sounds like she got it very early and that is an "excellent" thing. You both will be alright. Just take your time with all the info. coming your way - a lot is scary and most wont happen to her so try to take it with a grain of salt, if possible. I will say a prayer for your wife and you.  Keep in touch, and god bless you both. Best, Heidi

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 08:45PM - edited Jul 16, 2008 08:49PM by myheidiscrapbooking Hi honey, You sound young (going into College?) but you will survive surgery most definately!!!  and about Chemo, everyone reacts differently. If they put you on A/C (Adriamycn and Cytoxan) which is a normal routine chemo for Breast Cancer - they put you on that first (8 weeks) then they put you most likely on a diff. chemo after- Taxol/herceptin. This is a common common routine (I just finished both) last Thrus. Now start Radiation which most likely you will too.  I think that College might be hard on the AC treatment,  but the other is definately do-able!!! Most people have a lot of fatigue on AC and that may make it tough for you. I had a tough time fatigue wise but no other side-effect.  I know how scared you must be. I was diagnosed with one lump and when they got into surgery, they found 3 more so I know how you feel. Mine was in two of my lymphnodes as well. Have they mentioned anything about your lympnodes yet?  You have a right ot be scared. It is very very scary. My hardest time was at the time you are right now. I was soooooooooo overwhelmed and cryed all the time. It was awful. As you get to know your condition, diagnosis, ect, you start to feel better - more in control and you will feel better. There are SO many drugs now to combat Breast Cancer.  I also went on Zoloft for anxiety and that helped me a ton personally. Also, read all the subjects and mssg.s on this board and write anytime!!! Everyone here is going thru what you are or have already. There is so much great information. I found this board to be the support group I needed. It helped so much I can't tell you. Please keep us updated ok? and write again with any questions or updates. God bless you. You will be ok :)  Really! Big hugs, Heidi
